reviewText:
I have been a fan of Kingdom hearts for 11 years now and I must say all 7 games are wonderful. Kingdom Hearts 2 is still my number one fave out of the series, but this game held its own.

I am happy they changed it up with the spirits and creating them rather than sticking to donald and goofy. The spirits were a nice touch with their cuteness and usefulness.  I really enjoyed the drop because you were able to enjoy sora's and riku's story all at once.

I loved exploring the new worlds, and the trophy addition as well. The gameplay was fantastic and fresh....the flowmotion was fun and easy to control.  I liked how they have different modes like the other games and how they added a secret message and as always a secret ending.
I also enjoyed the mini games that they added into this game. KH DDD had much to do and did not get boring because of the many modes, trophies to collect, spirits to love and create...and of course leveling up and collecting every treasure chest.

The only flaw is I felt the main story was too short and they could of added more to the main story...as well the ending I was a bit disappointed with because I felt like there oculd of been more with the ending, it just halted to a stop to me.

over all it was an enjoyable game added to the series and I cannot wait until KH3 to come out.

This was a great game, overall.

The characters-Having played Coded, I wasn't surprised to play a KH game in which you can play as Sora and/or Riku. Sure they level up separately, but it's still fun playing as both. It may have been disappointing that there were no world specific party members, but the spirits in the game made up for that.

Story-It was shorter then Kingdom Hearts II, but still a amazing one. I wonder how Kingdom Hearts III will top this....

I can't say I wanted to know anything about Dream Drop Distance before I bought it. I'd definately reccommend it, though there are spoilers from the previous games in the series in the form of the chronicles option in the momento section of the main menu. Not that it's a bad thing. Especially if the player dosen't have a PS2 or a PSP.

Ok,
So I bought streetfighter for the 3DS and was so immensely disappointed in it, that I went to gamestop to trade in my game. They still gave me $7 for it, and in return I could only find a couple of games that could draw my attention.
Kingdom Hearts was NOT one of them!
I saw the movies, and honestly thought it was going to be about a story about Mickey mouse, and Donald Duck; but I was honestly mistaken!

It's a 3rd person swordslash (or key-blade slash) game where you go through levels beating monsters (aka dream eaters), and form your band of spirits (small animals that will help you out in your wars).

The personages are straight from a Japanese anime series, could be straight from a playstation too!
In few occasions you'll see a random movie of Disney characters, but they generally play little part in the game!

You go into disney worlds though, like enter the world of TRON, or of the hunchback notre dame.
But apart from that, there's really very little in common with the disney you used to watch as a kid!

The story line is a bit like WOW, in a sense, that you can do missions, do them halfway, and enter another mission. It's not an MMO, but you do can play against 4 other people with a 3DS.

The game has many parts to it.
First there's the regular story line. You follow it with your character.
Then there's your spirit animals, that are like a tamagochi, you need to feed it, and pet it, and learn it tricks.
You also can fight with it against other pets, using pokemon-like card games (with damage and defence).
It all sounds really boring, but it is quite time consuming.
You also have an extensive library of items to learn, as well as how to make spirits, and gain different weapons after every world you conquer.

Quite a few times in the game, there is no clear direction in where to go or what to do. Every time you unlock something, the game will show a card with lots of info on it. Too much to read, as it takes about a good 30 seconds to actually grasp and memorize what the card says.
As a result, most people just click it away, and try to discover that info by themselves, often frustrating themselves, because they can't find a certain portal or move, or defeat a certain weapon, because they did not read the info on the card.

Otherwise it's a nice game, but takes lots of your time. It's definitely nothing that you want to play just to fill up 5 minutes of your time.
It's the type that you play when you know you got the whole day ahead of you, and just want to lie in the couch, getting rid of your boring life!

I would recommend it to other people, just like Zelda or Mario Kart!
summary: More Japanese anime like than disney like!

reviewText:
I'm an avid Kingdom Hearts fan, and like most fans, i have been waiting for a game that will redeem the series. My first impression was that this was a game that you only fly around with. To my amusement, i found that wall jumping is only an added feature to make moving over big areas a lot easier! For the most part, it plays a lot like Birth By Sleep with the command decks except you don't meld commands anymore. You gain new commands and abilities from your dream eaters, which you create and have in your party to fight by your side. These little guys seem pointless at first, but you will soon realize there is a lot more to them than you thought. The worlds are great too, most of them are new so it's not like re-visiting an old place with minor changes for a 3rd, 4th or even 5th time. You start off in Traverse Town, which actually has a massive 4th and 5th district, also characters from "The World Ends With You" are here, meaning a first time for Kingdom Hearts to include non final fantasy characters. All in all a great game, bridges the gap between the second and upcoming 3rd game.

NOTE:
During the game, you unlock glossaries that discuss each other Kingdom Hearts game in a short summary. Very good feature for those that don't like to play the other spin-offs.

I love this game it was fun and i got this game because i wanted to further my knowledge of kingdom hearts and I Think the game gives a lot of good information but i would of liked if the game was a little bit longer and challenging because it took me 3 days to finish the game and it was on critical mode. Anyways if you love kingdom hearts and want to know about the next game you should buy this one.=)
summary: Great game, but is kind of easy

reviewText:
I pre-ordered the MoM edition for release date delivery. I'm still playing the game since that day. I'm currently 43 hours into the game on Proud mode with 38% of the story completed. Hence, you can tell I am taking my sweet time with the game unlike other people, who just rush through it for the story. I've played all of the localized released KH games, except for re:coded (which was originally a cell phone game). Birth by Sleep was my favorite game out of the KH series, but I think Dream Drop Distance can sit right next to it.

Story: A Dream? -----

I probably don't have to repeat it here as it's been posted, said and repeated a million times, but whatever...

You get that the story's gist is: Sora and Riku must enter the dreams of seven sleeping worlds as a part of their Mark of Mastery exam in order to become full-fledged keyblade masters. However, a mysterious boy shows up trying to "incept" the exam and throw some riddles at both of them. Who he is and why he resembles Xehanort when he was a young boy, we'll find out eventually at the end. In the world of the waking, everything may seem fine on their end, but they're not....??  Remember this: "Darkness becomes light and light falls into darkness."

If you're a KH newbie, there are Chronicle entries that you can read in this game, that are unlocked as you go through it, explaining to you what happened in the previous KH games. Unlike other game series out there, KH is one big continuous storyline ala Harry Potter. So, you'll come across a plot point that won't be answered until a future game. I highly recommend you guys to Google the "KH Info Block", because that Tumblr explains certain plot details a little better than the Chronicles. The Chronicles are still alright for giving you guys a good gist of the story. If you ever think about playing some of the past KH games, go in release order. You can try the official timeline order, but things work out better, both story and gameplay-wise, in release order.

(Out of all the KH games, re:coded holds the least importance to the story so you can skip that one if you want, and watch the ending cutscenes on Youtube.)

For KH fans/veterans, the story pacing has improved a lot from its early days of KH1, CoM and 2. It is also paced a little differently than Birth by Sleep, because you're dealing with two characters who battle in separate identical worlds instead of three characters trying to find one another in three separate storylines. Overall though, Dream Drop Distance works almost just like Birth by Sleep, but you're playing the two storylines at the same time. You no longer have to switch out of one character's file just to go to another character's file. That's why the Drop system exists for that purpose, however, I'll get into that a little later.

In each world, you won't find NPCs, except for Moogles and a particular Dream Eater, that you can simply walk up to and talk to them. All of the NPC conversations are in cutscenes, but they can be replayed again in the Flashback section of your Momentos menu.

Going back to DDD's pacing a bit, each world makes you go on a "mini quest" to do something for the NPCs who live there. Thus, it is a different type of interactive feel compared to trying to find a button behind a wall in Cinderella's house. However, each world holds a moral/theme that's actually important enough that both Sora and Riku keep reflecting on them. Some people seem to not look at Sora and Riku's thoughts/feelings. They just see the Disney worlds as they are calling them "filler", but they're not. You'll also be "interrupted" by someone, or some people, in each world that is/are related to the story's main villain, Xehanort. After beating each world, you'll see the other half of the story as to what's going on in the waking world. If you've seen the trailers, you can kind of picture how the beginning of that portion unfolds.

The System -----

Like the previous KH games, you are offered three different difficulty levels: Beginner, Standard, and Proud. If you complete Proud mode, then, you can unlock Critical mode. I highly recommend Proud mode. It's an improvement mode over Birth by Sleep, where the Unversed there were very easy to triumph over after just leveling up a few levels. In other words, there was a lack of a need to grind in Birth by Sleep throughout most of the game. That was the main disappointing thing in BbS that I had an issue with. However, in Dream Drop Distance, we can grind once more with enemies that are push overs.

For the two 3DS screens, the top shows your gameplay and cutscenes. The bottom screen functions as a world's map (which can be enlarged or shrunk), access to setting up a Link portal, checking up on what you need to do (via story), interacting with the Link ability system, and doing any Dream Eater training related activity.

The menu system, itself, is just like the previous KH games, but probably the most similar to the Birth by Sleep menu system. What's new about it is the Momentos section, which I already explained above. In that section, you can view past cutscenes, tutorials and other review type of information. Very easy to read and digest.

The camera system works the same way the first Kingdom Hearts game worked, but a little more stable where it does follow your character around more. You use the L and R buttons to pivot the camera, but I don't really use it so much. Some people think the camera follows the character too closely, but it's not that big of an issue to me.

Gameplay and Monsters Galore -----

One good chunk of the physical gameplay relies on "Flowmotion" where you parkour off walls, lightpoles, stair railings, strings of light, etc. and etc. It's a little bit of what some people would call, "the battle system on crack". You can even use it to scale up buildings such as Notre Dame. However, it's not invincible against enemies. Some of the enemies will be able to interrupt your Flowmotion with their own attacks. So, you can't always rely on it for everything.  If you ever do feel that Flowmotion is overpowering you, you do have the option to turn it off in the menu. However for me, I'm completely fine with it as it's fun to use and makes traveling through the big worlds much easier. You'll also be able to unlock the normal platforming abilities in this game. How you choose to use both systems are all up to you. You have the option to turn off abilities in your Command menu section.

Update 1: Sorry, forgot one thing. Reality Shift.  It's a system that involves both the air and the ground. When you're near Dream Eaters and objects, like barrels, a group of flashing pinkish/purpleish arrows show up. Slide down your stylus and you activate Reality Shift. There are different Reality Shifts per world each fitted to that world's theme. You might find some of them to be helpful when dealing with bosses and hordes of DEs.

The amount of Commands are less in Dream Drop Distance than in Birth by Sleep, but they still pack a punch. It seems that Square Osaka (- Square-Enix's division in the western part of Japan, who made Birth by Sleep -) were able to pick out some of the popular ones from BbS into Dream Drop Distance. At the same time, they invented some new Commands, which are just as awesome. Unlike Birth by Sleep, you don't level up these Commands. What you have to level up, besides Sora and Riku, are your Dream Eaters. In Birth by Sleep, you had Shot-locks and Dual Linking. In DDD, the same can still be seen when you link up with your Dream Eater. Certain Dream Eater abilities look exactly like Shot-locking. Just minus the target icon.

Dream Eaters are indeed cute and colorful looking residents of the dreaming universe. There are two kinds of Dream Eaters. The ones that are good are called "Spirits". The bad ones are known as "Nightmares". Despite their appearances, the enemy Dream Eaters do get really powerful and menacing if you're not too careful. Their A.I.s are MUCH better than Donald and Goofy's so that's how good they are to you. Sometimes, I would let them battle some DEs for me in order to succeed in a "Special Portal", where I'm not allowed to get hit more than two times. (Portals will be explained later.)

You're responsible for taking care of your Dream Eaters in order to level them and their abilities, up. Taking care of them are similar to Nintendogs/cats "petting the pet" effect, but these rubs and pokes are effective towards your Dream Eaters' Link Points and EXP as well. For a certain number of pokes and rubs you do on a Dream Eater, you can change their "Disposition" levels in order to unlock new abilities. What's amusing about these Dream Eaters, they each have their own personalities. Some are very happy, while others can be very moody and are easily prone to anger management problems. The pickier Dream Eaters can be harder to train.

You can also play a few mini-games with the Dream Eaters that go into their EXP level.  The only slight downside for some people with the Dream Eaters are: if you switch a Dream Eater out of your party for a different DE, you lose all the resistance abilities (i.e. Dark Screen) that you gained with that particular DE. If you want them back, all you have to do is switch that DE back into your party. Despite saying all that, Sora/Riku can do pretty well with a lack of resistance abilities on hand. It doesn't bother me one bit, at least. For some other people, they just want to keep that resistance level all the way through, regardless of the Dream Eater they have in their party.

Speaking of Dream Eater resistance abilities, you'll be leveling up your Dream Eater through an Ability Link status matrix grid system. The more Ability Link points your Dream Eater gains while fighting against other Dream Eaters, the more abilities you can unlock on the matrix grid.

In Birth by Sleep, you level up Commands and fuse them together with a crystal in order to get a new Command. In DDD, you mix Dream Eater ingredients with Commands in order to create new Dream Eaters. So, the process of combining something with something else is still there. You're just not required to constantly level up new Commands to level 3 or 4. Leveling up newly acquired Dream Eaters have taken that place. You may also not be using all 50 Dream Eaters, however, in order to gain one of the completion trophies, you will need to make all 50 Dream Eaters. Before you can even make a Dream Eater, you will need to find that Dream Eater's recipe scattered about in the seven worlds.

Drop System -----

The other main component of the game's system is the Drop System, which makes you switch between Sora and Riku in intervals of 20 minutes each. There's a bonus countdown that kicks in towards the end of your Drop gauge where you can get extra items from enemies. That's if you choose to do it by any means.

When the game first came out in Japan, I was completely worried about this because I had nightmares of time limit gameplays with Majora's Mask. Even some of the Japanese fans were ripping it apart. I am seriously NOT a fan of time limits. I love taking my time and exploring the worlds of games. I could tolerate them in Birth by Sleep, but something like Majora's Mask's three day system (which can be countered by a song) was scary.

However, to my pleasant surprise, it's very very veeery easy to counter the Drop system with items that you can buy early on in the game starting at the affordable price of 40 munny. (You can buy up to 99 of them so you have plenty of time to spare.) One such item is the one in my subject line, "Drop-Me-Not", which resets your Drop counter one-two bars back. In the future portion of the game, you can also purchase a "Drop-Me-Never", which completely resets your Drop counter back to however it started.

Another way to elongate your time is by obtaining Drop Points that you get when you fight enemy Dream Eaters. During the process of "Dropping", you'll be shown a menu of choices that affect the character that you'll be switch to. One of these choices is a "Drop Decelerator", which slows down your Drop gauge in three different speeds. The more Drop Points you obtain, the easier chances you can obtain the highest level of the Decelerator.

Thus, I encourage you guys to spend a lot of time per character/world grinding and fighting DEs so you can get the desired number of Drop Points. This particularly works well in Proud mode. I hear that Standard mode is sort of easy. (For Proud, it's probably not easy to do this in the beginning of the game, but a little later on, I find that spending an hour or two in one world can net me, at least, 200 DPs easily.)

Any remaining Drop Points get turned into munny, which can be used for more Drop-Me-Nots, so it's a fair deal.

If you ever come across people constantly complaining about Dropping constantly in the middle of boss battles or exploring in their games, there is something completely wrong with this picture. Some of these people do not know that Drop-Me-Nots exist so they keep playing through the game allowing the system to Drop for them. (Thus, thinking that the game "forces" them to rush.) You can also Drop yourself any time you want in the game via save points, accessing the menu, or putting the game on pause. So, you actually have full control of how you want to play the game rather than let the game play you. Couple that with the Drop-Me-Nots and highest Decelerator level, and you can play both characters for as long as you want. You just can't progress past a certain number of worlds as one character until you beat the other character's required portion of worlds. Their stories are suppose to play out in synch. Not separate like Birth by Sleep.

I would recommend playing as one of character's world stories all out first before Dropping to another character's story and play that from beginning to end. That way, you wouldn't get that "lost" feeling of trying to remember what happened before you were there. (Though, you could consult the Momentos section just for a memory refresher.)

Other people think they can only put the Drop-Me-Not in their active Command deck and it interrupts with their battles. For me, I put my Drop-Me-Not in the second Command deck, which is void of any Commands. It's very easy to go into the Command menu, switch to the second Command deck, press the X button for Drop-Me-Not, go back into the Command menu and switch back to my active Command deck. It only takes a few seconds to do this. You can make up to three Command decks, but I think one is enough for me and some other people to go by if you like mixing up your Commands once in awhile.

Note of caution: Being hit by some Dream Eaters may cause your Drop Gauge to speed up a little so that adds a teeny bit of challenge to your time management. It's not really that much of an issue when you have Drop-Me-Nots at your disposal.

The Seven Sleeping Worlds -----

You go through seven huge worlds. Some of them, you've been to before, but they're expanded. You may think you knew one area so well, but turn a corner, and you may find yourself becoming lost in it (which is good in my book). In true KH fashion, you'll find most of them to be "empty" except with Moogles and unlimited Dream Eaters/Tron NPCs. So, it's not really a surprise if you're use to this from the past KH games. The only difference here is that you won't be bumping into any standing non-Moogle NPCs. As I said earlier in this impression/review, they're all accessed through cutscenes.

For this kind of game, I don't mind there being a lack of standing non-Moogle NPCs, because they'll be in the way of the Flowmotion. Furthermore, coming across them, they'll usually say the same things over and over when you talk to them. Thirdly, I don't see any way you could incorporate non-Moogle NPCs in this game as all the worlds are in dreamland dreaming up of only the "important" characters of their respective worlds. Thus, these worlds are not the true versions of themselves. And yet, I have a feeling we can never truly know what's real or not later on in the game.

The Portals -----

There are four types of portals that exist in DDD.

One is a "Dive" portal that is used to travel between worlds that replace the existence of Gummi ships/shape-shifting keyblades. You only have to do them once per character and world, but you can replay them over and over in order to obtain certain abilities. Like KH2, traveling through a Dive portal is in the form of a mini-game. You'll come across some special Dive bosses in the midst of your travels. I enjoy the challenge of not being able to obtain the required amount of points or dying in these Dive portals. It makes you want to push your limit with what you can do.

The other three portals are Dream Eater related. One of them is the "Friendship" portal that lets you leave three DEs anywhere in the seven worlds, that will be found by other players via local wi-fi. Your DEs will be borrowed by those other players in order to fight the enemy DEs. The other portal works just like the friendship portal, except, it requires you to fight against the DEs that other players left for you.

If you don't know anybody nearby with DDD (that's like, the majority of KH players in the West), worry not. There are preset random A.I. portals that show up everywhere in the game. They all have Final Fantasy related names so you can't miss them.

The fourth portal is strictly an A.I. set up challenge type of portal that's known as "Special". Each Special portal you find gives you a requirement you must fulfill in order to make a mark of accomplishment in your Journal.

The Extra Content & Post-game Stuff To Do? -----

I previously explained that there are some mini-games you can do with Dream Eaters, while another one is the Dive portal system. The third one is the Flick Rush game, which is found in the first world (Traverse Town). It's a game that takes a little bit of patience and number skill to succeed through. Primarily, it works just like Chain of Memories' battle system, but at a faster pace and you must find a way to match up cards in order to get the upper hand. It's definitely a fun addicting mini-game. What you win from a Flick Rush round are a number of medals that can be traded in for abilities, items, etc. at the Moogle's medal shop. This is a refreshing change from seeing the Olympus Colosseum in almost every single KH game.

If you want the full experience of a game, you do your best on 100%ing the game. On top of collecting over 50 Dream Eaters, completing most of the DEs' matrix boards, and finding every single Comamnd/ability out there, there are 438 treasure chests to be found. For me, I try to find as many chests as I can while playing in the main story, rather then save it for post-game stuff. Some people do it that way, but I rather do it all before the final boss.

The amount of collectibles are smaller than how many collectibles you have to find in Birth by Sleep, but just like Birth by Sleep, there is a Trophy Shelf that needs to be fulfilled. Eighteen trophies to be exact. They are all mostly doable, except the questionable link portal trophy. So, these trophies add onto the re-playability. One of the trophies require you to beat the game in Critical mode.

As for what goes on post-game-wise, I know there is a New Game+, which is a little rare for a KH game. (Birth by Sleep touched "lightly" on this with Aqua.) I believe your Dream Eaters are carried over, but a lot of other things do not.

Music -----

Yoko Shimomura, Takeharu Ishimoto, and the rest of the DDD composers, arrangers and performers all deserve a big pat on their backs for creating another golden KH soundtrack. With everything from old songs we've heard before to new composed ones, there's nothing really much else I have to say with their music. It's magic. ^_^

Overall ----- <3

DDD is easily up there with Birth by Sleep for me in the favorite KH column. It's not a perfect game, but it's fun and won my heart easily. I wish you could be more interactive with your environments, beyond what they give you here in both BbS and DDD, and be able to unlock more hidden things/rooms/secrets. Also, I wish the portal system and Flick Rush game were open to global wi-fi instead of just local wi-fi. Those issues I have are minor compared to a lot of things that I do like in this game. (And if there's anything else I notice, I'll add it in here.)

Looking forward to seeing how this game sets everyone up for KH3. :)
summary: This game can Drop-Me-Not forever and ever and ever....[update 1]

reviewText:
In Kingdom Hearts 3D Dream, Drop Distance, for what feels like the first time in a long time the storyline moves forward. This news is especially good for those who like me have been long time followers of the series. I don't want to give away storyline specifics so I'll just give the general description of the story. Sora and Riku received a message at the end of Kingdom Hearts II which, as it turns out requested that they return to Yen Sid's tower because King Mickey and his friends are in desperate need of his help. There is an impending danger that our heroes will need to face and in order to do this they must gain a new power by taking the Mark Of Mastery exam. Which for our heroes is more like a trial by fire than an ordinary exam because in order to pass they must awaken seven sleeping worlds.

  Now I'll move on to gameplay. Starting in Traverse Town we are introduced to a game mechanic known as flow motion. Flow motion makes the environment around you more interactive which can especially come in handy during battles. How it does this is for example you can slide down rails and bounce off walls ti create a more powerful finishing move. (For those of you who might be interested it is in Traverse  Town that Neku and the gang from The World Ends With You make their epic cameo). Another important gameplay mechanic is the use of Spirits, In terms of how the game is played your personal dream eater spirits take the place of Donald and Goofy who worked as Sora's sidekicks in previous titles. it is important to a)Make sure they don't die. b)Make sure you bond and interact with them. c) Make sure you dream link with them which depending on which character your currently playing with results in either Sora teaming up for powerful attacks or Riku's own attacks becoming more powerful. Finally, d)make sure you level up the ability links which gives both the Spirits and your characters new abilities. The third new game mechanic which at times can be the most frustrating is the addition of the "drop gauge." This mechanism leads to the forced switching between the Characters Of Riku and Sora. Although. at times dropping can be rather seamless between the characters I learned the hard way that you must keep your eye on the gauge before starting a boss fight or even a mini boss fight. I can't tell you how many times I was dropped when only one or two hits away from defeating a boss only to have to start over when dropped back to the character. The last gameplay mechanic I want to discuss is reality Shift. Reality Shift much like flow motion allows for further interaction with each world's environment. From the simplistic barrel throwing of Traverse Town to the interactive comic reality shift of The Three Musketeers world,

  Overall, I really love this game and in my opinion it puts Kingdom Hearts back on the map. I love the fact that even though it all connects to the game's storyline overall we get two perspectives and two different portions of the story of each world via Sora and Riku's respective visits. My favorite world was La cite Des Cloches where we meet the cast of The Hunchback Of Notre Dame, In terms of the storyline it was a segment in which I enjoyed both perspectives. Aesthetically I most loved Symphony of Sound A.K.A. Fantasia world. It was so bright and colorful. The reality shift I enjoyed most is in The Three Musketeers world where you can beat some enemies through an interactive comic strip. My least favorite world is as in previous KH games Monstro I always get so lost in there!
I recommend the game to any KH fan, After the abomination that was Re Coded we all so deserved this.

A world filled with Disney and Final Fantasy-themed characters was certainly never something anyone asked for, but it's added up to quite the fascinating franchise in the form of Kingdom Hearts, which has always sported a distinct mixture of doe-eyed innocence and encroaching darkness. Kingdom Hearts 3D: Dream Drop Distance marks the series' seventh installment overall, and the fifth on a handheld console. While a vast majority of the Kingdom Hearts games have been spinoffs of the primary two (with KH3 being so long delayed), oftentimes featuring storylines of side characters that generally add up to prequels or epilogues, Dream Drop Distance returns to the core storylines of main characters Sora and Riku, although it's never made entirely clear where this particular timeline falls (it is rumored, however, that this game's ending ties directly into KH3, which series director Tetsuya Nomura has supposedly insisted will be the next release). The Kingdom Hearts storyline as a whole is rather convoluted and a bit melodramatic, but very moving and thought-provoking nonetheless. For those initially unfamiliar with the finer details (like myself-this is admittedly the first KH title I've personally played), all you need to know for now is this: best friends Sora and Riku are prompted by the powerful wizard Master Yen Sid (the elderly wizard from Disney's Fantasia) to take the Mark of Mastery Exam in preparation for an approaching threat to multiple worlds. Although they both have already been awarded keyblades, powerful weapons used to correct the balance between light and darkness in the world as needed, they must complete this test before they may be deemed true Keyblade Masters and gain access to the power they'll need for the evil that approaches. This test requires them to enter a series of worlds which were in one timeline destroyed by the Heartless (physical manifestations of darkness, beings devoid of emotion, oftentimes in the guises of Disney and Final Fantasy-themed villains throughout the series) and then restored, but somewhere in between fell into a deep sleep that rendered them incapable of connecting with one another. In an effort to properly "awaken" and interconnect the worlds to restore balance once again, Sora and Riku must unlock the seven Sleeping Keyholes, each of which lies somewhere within a sleeping world.

Early on in this test, the bright-eyed Sora and brooding Riku are separated from one another, hurled into separate versions of the same worlds. This adds up to separate but interconnecting timelines in which different events occur in the same locations/periods, which also ties directly into the gameplay: in KH3D, you'll spend half the time playing as Sora and half the time playing as Riku, each of whom maintains his own separate progression in each world. This is a unique feature that also incorporates the new "Drop" system, which sets off a timer each time you begin adventuring with one of the two heroes. This `timer' comes in the form of the Drop Gauge, which slowly depletes but can reduce or increase quicker depending on what types of items or techniques you use. Once the Drop Gauge hits zero and your time's up, your current character will "Drop," at which point he'll immediately stop whatever it is he's doing and retreat into a sleeping state; then the storyline will switch and you can begin playing as the other character with his own renewed Drop Gauge. This might sound wonky at first but it actually adds an exciting sense of urgency and time progression, encouraging you not to neglect one storyline in favor of the other (they both thankfully tend to remain pretty engaging). You can use items such as Drop-Me-Nots to extend the duration of your Drops, and you can also Drop at will as needed, but keep in mind what you do in one storyline can sometimes affect the other: throughout battles you'll collect Drop Points, which can be used at the end of each Drop to give various boosts to the character you're switching over to, such as increases in attack power, defense, Drop duration and more. You sometimes won't be able to advance to the next section of the world map until you complete a world with both Sora and Riku, so there are many tactical decisions to consider throughout each Drop. My only gripe about this feature is the fact that if you Drop during a boss battle, you'll have to start it over when you Drop back, which can expectedly be really obnoxious, especially for lengthy ones. Because of this I'd recommend keeping watch of your Drop Gauge especially before specific encounters and equipping Drop-Me-Nots as needed.

The combat in KH3D is very fast-paced and exciting, and definitely among the game's brightest highlights. Somewhat like a mish-mash of popular MMOs, Kid Icarus: Uprising and various Legend of Zelda titles, you'll rely on different types of melee weapons (i.e. keyblades) and magic spells to attack enemies from either afar or in the fray. KH3D marks the return of the battle deck, a handy system that allows you to set a customizable series of attacks and abilities for use on the battlefield. You can create separate decks (such as one focused mainly on fire-based attacks, one mainly on healing HP, a balanced mix of everything, etc.) and whip them out from the Pause menu as needed. The deck automatically switches through your magic in the order you select from the deck creation menu as you use each ability; you can also use the D-pad to manually backtrack or swap around mid-combat to particular ones, but each move has a cooldown period you'll have to wait through before a successive use. Expectedly, very powerful/useful abilities have longer cooldowns, so you'll have to consider this when building your decks. There are a vast variety of magic abilities, with spells that can set foes aflame, freeze them, trap them in midair gravity vortexes, home in on them from afar, cure your HP or relieve you of status conditions and much more. Veterans of the series will fondly remember the igniting Firaga, electrifying Thundara and ever-useful Curaga. As you progress through the game you'll earn different and increasingly powerful magic spells for your deck in addition to new keyblades for slashing melee strikes. The X button is used to call forth magic spells from your deck while the A button initiates physical attacks and keyblade combos. With several dozen types of enemies and bosses with varying resistances and weaknesses (as you might expect, water-based foes tend to feel the hurt against electricity and icy enemies don't fancy fire), there's a lot to consider (and enjoy).

An importantly integrated new feature is that of the Dream Eaters, colorful, cuddly critters found commonly as both friends and foes throughout the game. Friendly Dream Eaters are known as Spirits, and they will be absolutely essential to your arsenal in combat. You can create Spirits from Dream Pieces you gather as you battle, and there are a great deal of recipes that make for all types of useful creatures, whether it be an HP-recovering flower or ferocious T-Rex. This adds a very Pokmon-esque element to the game as you level up your Spirits to become stronger and gain new powerful abilities as they fight alongside you in each and every battle. You'll use a Final Fantasy-inspired Ability Link table to progressively unlock new abilities, which will also have direct effects on Sora and Riku. Spirit abilities can in fact come in the form of stat boosts, so using certain Spirits who've gained certain abilities can allow increased resistances to certain attack types or even immunities to certain status conditions. In other words, these little guys can offer both an offensive and defensive edge. They can also unlock brand new magic spells for Sora and Riku to use, in addition to their own attacks to initiate mid-battle. In order to increase a Spirit's Link Points (used to progress through their Ability Link table and gain new abilities), you'll have to play with and feed them, very similar to a Nintendog or a Tamagotchi. You do so by petting them on the touchscreen with your stylus from the pause menu, which is also where you can toss them cakes, cookies and other treats to increase their stats. While it's adorable at first, it becomes tedious as the game progresses, and the fact that it's the only way to push Spirits to their maximum potential becomes pretty obnoxious. Thankfully the Spirits are at least very nice to look at, with quite literally every one sporting colorful, detailed and ultra-cute designs (you'll be very motivated to catch `em all). Be warned, by the way: prevent your Spirit from dying in battle at all costs, because if it does, it reverts back into Dream Pieces. You can recreate it, but it will lose all of its learned abilities and start back at its initial level. Luckily you'll be warned when they're in danger, and you'll have the opportunity to go save them (this also won't be a problem nearly as often as you might think unless you take low level Spirits into intense fights).

One of the greatest features of Spirits is the ability you'll have to "Link" with them; as they fight with you and gain affinity for you (which happens as you battle with them often, play with and feed them), their Link Gauge, which is displayed on the touchscreen, increases. Once it's hit its maximum, you can tap the Spirit's icon to Link with it, which can cause one of two in-battle events depending on who you're playing as. Sora becomes able to initiate a series of super-attacks (or one single powerful one) with the Spirit itself for a certain period, while Riku physically merges with the Spirit and gains one of its abilities himself. If both Link Gauges are full, you can even Link with both of your Spirits at once for an even more devastating Link attack. The Link abilities range from showering the battlefield in damaging light while fully healing your entire party to swishing around with bat wings and initiating lethal dark magic-infused combos. The individual and combo Links vary depending on your Spirits, and it's great fun to experiment with them and their bedazzling visuals.

Another new feature exclusive to KH3D is Flowmotion, a unique ability that allows Sora and Riku to air dash and launch themselves off walls to climb up them, attack enemies, or move very quickly throughout the area. You can also use Flowmotion to swing around poles or slide along grind rails. This is a very welcome addition and should in all honesty become a series staple, as it allows for fantastic maneuverability and thrilling battle sequences. Although it can feel unwieldy at first, once you've practiced a bit you just might start to wonder how you progressed through any game ever without it. Reality Shifts, meanwhile, allow Sora and Riku to enter portals that allow them to bend the rules of time and space; activate one and gameplay will shift to the touchscreen, initiating one of several mini-games (they differ by world) tying into the current theme; cracking codes in Tron: Legacy's Grid will allow you to manipulate surrounding technology, while you can create unhappy comic endings for cartoony baddies in the Country of the Musketeers. Features like this offer some very exciting gameplay changeups throughout.

As KH fans have surely come to expect, you'll progress through a series of Disney-themed worlds featuring familiar scenery, characters and self-contained story arcs (the best of which tie into the central plot). Tron: Legacy and Pinocchio all make for beautiful backdrops, but I was never personally the biggest fan of Hunchback of Notre Dame (although it does make for some well-designed stage terrain and shockingly dark storyline action), and The Three Musketeers was flat out a poor choice (it is overall the dullest, most inane world here). The Fantasia world in particular, however, features an array of intoxicating visual splendor, and the fact that most sound effects are shut off in favor of the warmly familiar musical scores makes for a truly immersive thematic experience. The thrilling, heart-racing, generally epic boss battles at the end of each world are among the game's most memorable highlights, featuring once again a mix of Disney/Square Enix-themed baddies. You'll see some awesome familiar faces in addition to some startling new ones.

Along the lines of flaws, there certainly are a few but thankfully nothing prevents the game from being generally great. For one, the game unfortunately sports a particularly wonky and uncooperative camera that ordinarily has to be manually moved to the direction most people would prefer (a problem I've heard has actually been plaguing most of the series). You can lock on to specific enemies to make focal points easier to keep track of, but occasionally your lock will seemingly cancel at random, which can prove very frustrating in intense boss battles. Additionally, while most of this RPG's platforming is pretty smooth, oddball ticks in stage environments can make for off-kilter interaction, as you may be unable to jump on or Flowmotion across certain things you'd strongly expect to be able to. There are also odd and vaguely sporadic instances of lag after using certain attacks and particularly after blocking attacks; Sora and Riku will sometimes behave as though they are briefly stunned from shielding, particularly after using several successive attacks or when there's a lot going on. Whether this was intentional or not, at its worst your movement will feel clunky in spurts (which can be a total buzzkill in the frantic pace of certain boss fights). Keep in mind, however, that KH3D's strengths so far outshine its weaknesses that very, very few players are likely to walk away sincerely saying they were wholeheartedly dissatisfied with the overall experience.

KH3D as a whole is overall glorious to behold, with beautifully rendered cutscenes featuring spot-on voice acting (much of the star-studded original cast returns) and a generally gorgeous visual style ensuring you're never bored with what you see onscreen. This game really shows what the 3DS is capable of, and what will hopefully be further utilized in the future. Although its storyline strays a bit far from the core plot at times and will definitely confuse newbies, everything comes together during its particularly epic conclusion, as things fluidly segue into what all KH fans have been eagerly waiting for. Whether you're a dedicated longtime fan or a 3DS owner looking for some fast-paced, aesthetically pleasing action, Kingdom Hearts 3D is an absolute must-have.
summary: You won't want this dream to end

reviewText:
The Good:

+Great, fluid combat mechanics
+A large story that'll keep you busy
+Fantastic production values

The Bad:

-The story will be pretty confusing if you don't remember the other games
-The "drop" system feels gimmicky

In recent memory, most of the Kingdom Hearts spinoffs have been hit or miss. Games like Re:Coded, which don't really add as much to the series as one expects. But then you have a game like Birth By Sleep that's a fantastic game. Kingdom Hearts Dream Drop Distance (or 3D, if you must) is more in touch with Birth By Sleep. And, in fact, those who played Birth By Sleep will get so much more out of it. Dream Drop Distance is by far one of the better Kingdom Hearts spinoffs out there, and one that Kingdom Hearts fans with a 3DS should play.

The story centers on Sora, Riku and Mickey as they take the trials to become keyblade masters. They must go through a series of challenges to prove themselves. Unfortunately things get a little messed up in the process and it involves a much bigger adventure at play. The story can seem just a tad bit confusing, but this is because it relies on you having knowledge of prior games. It'll try its best to catch you up to speed but in the long run, it's best to actually play prior games (in particular: Birth By Sleep). You're going to meet a few new characters (Neku from The World Ends with You shows up here) and a few old. You'll also travel to various Disney worlds just as you've done before.  This is not a game for first time players of Kingdom Hearts.  The story is not as simple as it seems and Dream Drop Distance is going to be confusing to anyone who decides to start their Kingdom Hearts romp here.

Kingdom Hearts 3D plays a lot like it's older brothers on the PS2, DS and PSP, but here things are more refined. A lot of the Kingdom Hearts spinoffs have done quite a few things to mess with the system at play. While the gameplay remains familiar in Dream Drop Distance, there area few things added. You'll begin by playing a combat tutorial that will definitely give you a run down. The games basic structure hasn't changed. It's still an action RPG through and through where you can lock on to targets and attack them. While also manipulating through various spells and techniques. After using each spell or technique it's going to recharge before you do it again. This keeps one from spamming everything and keeps Dream Drop Distance from being too touch. Likewise, you'll gain more ability slots and be able to set more as you go.

There are a few additions to combat, though, such as the reality shift. When locked onto enemies the cursor will become pink and you can engage in a Reality Shift attack. These attacks change based on your location. In Traverse Town, for instance, it's a slingshot that will allow you to fling objects (or enemies) at other foes. You can also do flow motion attacks where you use the objects and environments around you to go ahead and pull off other attacks.

The biggest addition is how the team mechanics are done. There's no Donald and Goofy to team up with this time around. Instead you'll have to contend with Dream Eaters. These Dream Eaters are the ones invading the worlds you must save. But there are also friendly Dream Eaters called spirits that you can create using materials you gain from fallen foes (called Nightmares). They're more or less your pets and they'll help out in battle. If you spend time with them and care for them you can build up their stats.

You'll play as both Sora and Riku throughout the experience. But Dream Drop Distance utilizes a "drop" system. Both character's have a drop gauge and when it depletes entirely that character will "drop" and you'll pick up as the other character. This can even happen in the middle of combat or when you're simply running around. The system in and of itself can feel very strange at first (especially when you drop in the middle of a fight) and it's likely to rub some people the wrong way. The good news is that you can also drop manually if you feel like it. And if you're wise about how you do it you won't drop in the middle of a tough fight. That being said, when you resume it's not s though you'll find yourself right in the thick of a boss fight. The battle will reset.

The game is telling two parallel stories so when you "drop" and the other character takes over it's not from where one left off. Sora and Riku will both be doing their own thing in the same area and starting off from their own point. The drops will not be a surprise as you'll always know when they're coming and you'll be able to prepare accordingly.

Kingdom Hearts Dream Drop Distance is a great game, but definitely not perfect. The only thing that may seem a bit odd is that there's a lot to learn about the combat of the game. Things get off to a slow and awkward start as the game constantly bombard's you with tutorials, explanations and flashbacks. It doesn't settle into a good groove for quite some time. Kingdom Hearts games usually have lengthy prologues or tutorials, but they're usually integrated in a way that doesn't break up the flow of the game itself. Dream Drop Distance is constantly stopping combat and story to do so. And while it is most certainly important to learn the game the rate at which these tutorials come is more than likely going to make the player feel overwhelmed.

The second thing that's hard to overcome is that the mechanic of "dropping" just seems gimmicky in and of itself. The story and game itself offer up little reason for it to be implemented. The game could've easily told two parallel stories in a fashion similar to how Birth By Sleep did it's simultaneous story lines. Instead we have a drop mechanic. It's a good thing they let you also drop manually. The point is, the mechanic in and of itself still feels very gimmicky and of all the things that Dream Drop Distance does this may be the one that you'll care for the least.

The 3DS has a wide range of good looking games. Kingdom Hearts 3D is by far one of the better looking on the system. While games like Resident Evil Revelations do a great job at what they do, Kingdom Hearts is colorful and vibrant. Sometimes even looking better and smoother than the PS2 older brothers. The environments are incredibly detailed and populated. The frame rate never dips or slows down and it's just easy on the eyes. The 3D isn't bad either, but like most 3DS games, isn't really integral to the visual experience of the game itself. The music is very good, though most tunes are familiar. They're either remixed from older Kingdom Hearts titles or ripped directly from them. From a production standpoint a 3DS game has rarely looked this good.

In the end, for Kingdom Hearts fans, Dream Drop Distance is a great game that really adds to the story and mythos at hand. It's worth playing.

I've been a fan of the "Kingdom Hearts" franchise for a while, but even the most devout followers have begun to grow weary of its publisher's practice of shelling out prequels, in-between-quels, and all-over-the-place-quels. In all of these games, the gameplay remains fundamentally unchanged, with the exception of "Re:Coded", which was otherwise a disappointment in my book. It seemed that, on the surface, Square Enix was simply jumping on the 3DS bandwagon and shelling out another half-baked entry in order to stall before people tore down their door and demanded Kingdom Hearts III already. Regardless, I decided to give this the benefit of the doubt, and I'm pleased to announce that this is the best game in the series since "KHII". In fact, it may arguably be the best entry yet.

We join Sora and Riku after the events of II and "Re:Coded". Riku is playing for the good guys again, teaming up with Sora to take on the Mark of Mastery exam. This involves them travelling to various worlds in order to find hidden keyholes that will prove their meddle as true Keyblade Masters. The plot is a welcome change of pace from the treacly sentimentality of "358/2 Days", the rehashed narrative in "Birth By Sleep", and the confused logic and pacing of "Re:Coded." Nomura and all others involve certainly listened to the critics when it came to the story in this entry, and gave us what we wanted: a true follow-up. Much in the vein of "Chain of Memories", "Dream Drop Distance" expands on world of the game without losing its focus, and never gets lost trying to pander to fans. The result is the most focused game yet, and one whose story is filled with enough emotion and excitement for any gamer to enjoy. That being said, it's best to be familiar with the franchise before tackling this one. Newcomers may feel a little bit lost.

My main concern about "DDD" was definitely the gameplay, given that it hasn't really changed in several years. All fears have been put to rest now, due to the fact that the dev team definitely took their time with making a fun and balanced experience. The level-based hack-n-slash we're used to is still here, but it's aided by the addition of a new system called "Flowmotion." This is a snazzy way of saying that Sora and Riku now fancy themselves to be masters of parkour. The real surprise here is that Square Enix managed to slide in a new gameplay feature without turning it into a convoluted wreck. Flowmotion works fabulously. Within a few minutes of playing, you'll be grinding off of rails, using enemies as pommel horses, and careening off walls hundreds of feet in the air. Doing this allows you to deliver devastating special moves on enemies. Every enemy encounter, and especially every boss stage, transcends typical button-mashing battles and turns into something more visceral and downright fun than I ever expected from this franchise.

The other addition is the "Drop" feature. You'll be playing as both Sora and Riku in this game, as they battle through parallel worlds to find the hidden keyholes. This works in a very unique way; you have a time with each character, as they experience different narratives in the same worlds. You have to beat the world with both characters in order to truly beat it and progress the story. This is less cumbersome than it sounds, and is in fact a very interesting way to approach handling both characters. You can also jump to another character early by using the "Drop" button on the pause menu. This can be handy if you get to a good stopping point in one character's progression. Getting to experience both characters' unique perspectives is a welcome change in pace for the series.

Another worth mentioning, if only for a few sentences, is the addition of Spirit companions. Much like the world-specific partners of previous games, these animals fight side-by-side with you and can be teamed up with for a special attack. However, it works in a similar fashion to the "Shin Megami Tensei", where you collect certain components of the monsters, then combine them in order to create them. Depending on how many components you have, you can alter the strength and abilities of the monsters. You can have three with you at any given time, and I highly recommend you do so. These partners are very helpful, and fun to customize and level up. The interface for leveling them is very similar to a virtual pet simulator by way of "Final Fantasy X"'s level system. It's not too complicated, but not overly simplistic. Just the right balance of strategy and fun make this a worthwhile component to an already great game.

Graphically, this is the best-looking game in the series, without a doubt. Having played several 3DS titles, I can firmly say this is the prettiest one yet, and clearly demonstrative of what we can expect from Square Enix in the near future. Environments pop to life with dazzling use of textures and shadows, and everything blazes forward with no drop in the frame rate. From Notre Dame to The Grid, these are beautiful renderings of iconic settings, some of which have never been visited in the franchise before. The only negative is, unfortunately, the uneven use of 3D. Frame rate has a noticeable drop when the feature is used in some areas, yet flows smoothly in others. While the effects are nice and all, I would recommend only using it for cutscenes. The game actually stands very strong on its own graphical merits, and the effects steal the thunder a little bit.

Haley Joel Osment (remember him?) turns in another show-stealing performance as Sora, enough to make one wonder why he hasn't just decided to become a full-time voice actor already. The rest of the cast is predictably great, as is the music. The soundtrack once again spans a variety of styles, implementing the techno and trip-hop found in "The World Ends With You" when its characters are on-screen. There's nothing more to say, really, given that people already know Square Enix excels in this department.

Here we are, seven years after "Kingdom Hearts II" left us speechless, and we're finally given the sequel we've wanted for so long. According to series creator Nomura, "Kingdom Hearts 3D: Dream Drop Distance" is a taste of the gameplay we can expect from the third entry. If this is truly the case, then I say bring it on. This is the best entry in the "Kingdom Hearts" series so far, and a surefire candidate for Handheld Game of the Year. If you've been holding out because of Square Enix's incessant milking of the franchise, this is the one you've been waiting for.

Ironic. In creating the best game of this stellar series, the developers have created perhaps the best 3DS title yet.

Story: 9
Gameplay: 10
Graphics: 9
Sound: 10
Overall: 9.5

I have been a Kingdom Hearts fan since I bought the first game the day it came out. While I started to loose faith in the handheld titles, Birth by Sleep recaptured the imagination and amazing storytelling that sucked me into the series. The same team was put in charge of this title, and I truly hope they are in charge of the inevitable Kingdom Hearts 3 we have already waited 6 years for. I don't want to spoil anything, but as with all Kingdom Hearts titles you can guess the entire story from the intro video. Luckily this time it included the main plot points from every previous title in the series.

This game:
The graphics are amazing, even better than the PS2 sequences. The 3d adds even more depth to an already amazing game. I have 10 3ds games including LoZ:OoT, Starfox, and Mario 3d Land. Kingdom Hearts 3D definitely is the best 3d game I have seen to date.
Flow motion is a bit hard to get used to at first, but by the end of the first level it will be your main source of damage to enemies. If you were annoyed as I was at times at how long it took to get across the vast Kingdom Hearts maps, you will love this feature.
The Dream Eaters are cool in concept, and definitely make controlling Riku more awesome (try giving him wings). However, the developers attempted to make them Nintendogs meet Tomogatchi. Which means to make them truly useful in combat you need to show them affection and play minigames to fully power them up. Luckily to beat the game you don't technically have to participate in this side activity, but all of your stat boosts are dependent on doing this.
Spoiler for those who know nothing of the game/% There are seven worlds, each needs to have its keyhole locked to have Sora and Riku finish their Mark of Mastery Exam. Each world is split into two parts such that Sora and Riku can play the same world from different storylines and perspectives. %\ Each of the worlds in the game are "new." Even Traverse Town has a new and expanded twist with the addition of The World Ends With You characters and Shibuya style.
Dropping is my least favorite part of the game, but it does help propel the story. It takes a few drops to really get used to (especially if you are like me and attempt to grab every treasure chest on the first play through), but it forces you to keep up with the stories of both Sora and Riku. As much as dropping annoys me, I remember KH Chain of Memories where you had to play as Riku after Sora by which point you probably forgot part of the story. Or Birth by Sleep where you had to play the game from 3 different perspectives. The nice thing is that if you fall behind with a character, you can "drop" early and switch back to the other character.

Overall Kingdom Hearts 3D takes a little while to get used to, but once you get past the first hour or so of gameplay you will find so much to love. The character development, graphics, and battle system make this the most unique and arguably best handheld Kingdom Hearts to date. I have high hopes for what Square Enix will do with the third installment of this amazing series.

First time Kingdom Hearts Players: While I think the team did a great job of making the intro video tell the main story of the game, there is a lot of story to catch up on. I would suggest either finding a website with a description of the main parts of each game (most of the storyline will be "spoiled" by playing this game anyway), or make sure to read every report in your journal as you collect it. If you don't care about storyline, then this is a perfect starting point in the series. The battle system and worlds are a lot of fun, even if you don't know exactly what is going on in the grand scheme of things.
summary: Best Handheld Kingdom Hearts to Date

reviewText:
The vita version is a port of the psp version, I wish they would have based it off the console versions. The story is also hard to follow if you are not a Harry potter fan, but if you are not you most likely wouldnt be interested in the game anyway.

Pros
-Fun
-Great music
-Fun for all Ages
-Lego Charm

Cons
-Same old(still fun)gameplay
-Clunky story to follow
-Blurry cinematics

Game looks and plays like a PSP game on Vita. Lego games never had the reputation for good graphics.. but this one is terrible. Especially when they are charging a premium price for it. It should have been priced the same as PSP titles for what they have done. Simply download the PSP version from PSN and play it.. there is no real advantage in buying this at this price.

Game play's as good as it does on a PSP. Buy it when the price drops below twenty. I just wish the developer had done a decent job of porting the console version down to Vita.
summary: Poor port from PSP to PSV

reviewText: I had to get this even at full price because of the previous Ravenhearst games. It was worth it. This game is a little different from the other hidden objects parts of the two older games. You are not looking for items from a list, you are looking for morphing objects and you have an indicator of how many morphing objects you need to find in a scene. In the "casual" mode the hint button refreshes quickly but hints are not available on where to go next.  In this collector's edition the strategy guide gives VERY clear cut directions on what to do next if you get stuck or just want to check if you are on the right track. Just like the two older games the graphics are excellent, as are sound effects and voice acting. This is definitely another winner! I did have to look up a walkthrough on line for a few scenes that where complicated for me. The master detectives may not have any problems but there is walkthrough by Big Fish that gives a little more explanation to certain scenes if you need it.
summary: Great follow up to previous Ravenhearst Games!

reviewText: Good game
amazing product and faster shipping!!!

Ive lost count of how many times i have played the witcher 3.  I figured id go backwards and try the second one to get some insight on the story.  This felt very linear in comparison to the third installment.  I do not recommend going backwards in the series.  This game was somewhat disappointing for me.  The good news is that because it is older, most pcs with modest graphics cards can run this in ultra no problem, so the graphics felt similar to witcher 3 on console.  Play this as a game to get background knowledge, and invest your time and effort in the witcher 3 instead.
summary: Witcher 3 was a HUGE improvement over this

reviewText: I never have a problem hanging out with the White Wolf, but this time around he makes me dizzy and not in a good way.  Unlike the nice keyboard and mouse interface in the first game they are practically useless here.  You NEED a pc controller or you'll go as nuts as a drunkin alghoul.  also the graphics look a bit strange.  Another amazin romp but hindered by the interface.
This was epic and it had more cleavage, cannot wait to play the 3rd

The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings is a marked improvement over the original. With a much more interesting story, better battle mechanics, and characters with more life than cardboard cutouts, it is an improvement in every way. As always my reviews are split into 3 categories: Story, Gameplay, and Characters with the Story getting the most weight.

Story 8/10

The story in the second witcher game is very well written. You pick up right after the end of the first game protecting King Foltest. Soon after you are on the run from the law and are trying to clear your name. The story does a good job of building up over time until the ending which is fabulous. Overall the story suffers the same issue with timing as the original witcher. In both games, the story struggles to get going in the first chapter. Also, in many parts, the story is just difficult to follow. The game is another example of the writers assuming the player knows a lot about the lore of the witcher universe, or the multitudes of factions, and leaves details out which makes it difficult to piece together. Nonetheless, the story is engaging once you get it going about half way through the first chapter. And overall the ending is extremely satisfying.

Gameplay: 9/10

This is where the 2nd installment really shines. The gameplay was easily the weakest part of the first game but here you can tell the developers spent quite a bit of time fixing those issues. Gone are the time based rhythm attacks that were infuriating over the course of the first game. In the witcher 2, they have implemented a much more tactical battle mechanic which is a welcome addition.  Also implementing counter moves and blocking. BLOCKING. YES! They have also implemented a new battle menu system that makes it much easier to quickly switch Signs and putting things in your quick slots such as bombs and traps. The overall layout for leveling and maps are also much improved. They have also implemented things like armor and weapon upgrades that you can add certain attributes to your armor and weapons to give them added bonuses on the fly. Unfortunately, the game has several bugs in it that make some portion of the games nearly unplayable. One in particular was an optional boss fight that required you to extinguish torches so he could no longer summon monsters. Well the player can't select the torches to extinguish and instead just runs through them. Another glitch where a player has to let a certain NPC walk through a door first or the game crashes. Getting stuck in walls is a common problem. Other than the glitches,  the gamplay was much improved.

Characters: 8/10
So Geralt is still Geralt. Yet the voice actor seems to have improved since the first. He seems to have a bit of emotion now. Geralt is almost fully customizable when it comes to personality. Certain characters returning from the original are also well done like Triss, Dandelion, and Zoltan. New characters like Letho, and Roache really knock it out of the park as well. Some of the new ones though really don't do a lot or show me a lot. Sila for instance is just kind of....there. And it's unfortunate that if you side with Roache you almost don't experience Saskia at all as she seems to be one of the better characters in the game. Nonetheless, the characters are an improvement and overall do not detract from the game.

Overall 8/10

The Witcher 2 is a really fun game once you get going. They have improved the gameplay quite impressively and many of the characters are really a charm. If you can get through the first 5-8 hours of the game, the rest of it really is a treat.
summary: A marked improvement over the original

reviewText: Great game. Ridiculously fun,
The first ones graphical layout was cooler.

I picked up the Witcher 2 only recently, as the Witcher 3 came out and I had never actually bought the second one.  I played the first game when it came out and really liked it a lot as well, but when 2 came out, I wasn't gaming all that much, so it just got skipped over for a while.  Now, the Witcher 3 came out and I need a new video card to play it, so I picked up 2 while I save for a video card.

Anyway, the game itself is great.  Much like the first game, the storyline and lore is truly amazing, as is the soundtrack.  They have streamlined the quests much more so there is a lot less traveling and repetition in gameplay, which is for the better in most cases.  They have improved the combat system greatly from the first one as well (one of its weak points) which goes from a rhythmic clicking from the first one, to blocking, parrying and dodging attacks which makes combat a whole lot more fun.  After playing through the game twice, I was still walking around looking for fights in this game!

Mid-game, you have to pick which side you want to fight for, which completely changes Chapters 2 & 3 in the game.  This essentially gives you an extra 166% of the content if you go back and play it as the other side again.  Additionally, they supported the game for a long time after release, just like the first game.

The only real negatives in this game is while they have streamlined the quests and removed much of the excessive and repetitive traveling, the game is also much shorter than the first one, and many little things that may be quite difficult in the first game, such as hunting down ingredients for a specific potion is nowhere near as difficult anymore either.  Short of the ingredients to remove the tattoo, collecting ingredients seems a little too easy.
summary: Easily one of the greatest RPGs of all time

reviewText: one of best game ever made !!
Requires high levels of hand-eye coordination to win "boss-battles". Too much arcade game for my tastes. NOT like Skyrim.
summary: Certainly not like Skyrim because of required arcade game sequences,

reviewText:
How do you start a review of this game?  All I have to say is read the "read-me" file and you'll see this Enhanced edition fixes a lot of things!  You will also see in the readme file how much there is to this game, because of all of the issues, which either meant they were poor developers or the sheer size and complexity of the game warranted a HUGE read-me file of fixes.  You should also read the read-me file just for information about a great deal of things that pertain to the game. As a relative new-comer to this series that I am (before-hand:  I had played the first installment Witcher-1 on a PC of which I hated because it was a low end machine; I had taken my CRPG "hunt" to Skyrim in 2011 (via Oblivion 2008 and Morrowind 2002 of which I won't get into here and but played religiously until 2013 when my ps3 was stolen after Halloween of which the crime has not been solved)  yet:  a house-fire, renovation, displacement without a gaming machine, had devastated me until I got a laptop and downloaded some old DOS games via a certain site, and then another certain site had taken me to Witcher-2: Assassins Of Kings Enhanced, this version I am reviewing here.  I had also bought a PS4 in the fall of 2014 for the sole intention of playing Witcher 3 on it.  I played Dragon Age Inquisition and The Last Of Us on the PS4, both beautiful games but didn't quite scratch that Skyrim itch), I went to the Good Old Games and found Arx Fatalis, which lead me to this game of which I had ignored because I was lost in Skyrim at time when it was released.  So! Here I am wondering what to do before the Witcher 3 release, and what luck! I found it's predecessor!  Things are going my way!  I can now prepare for the game of the decade, Witcher 3 (or maybe the century) by playing a microcosm of it:  Witcher 3. The developers of Witcher 3 proclaim that it is 35 times larger than Witcher 2 and two times larger than Skyrim!  There are so many reasons I am waiting to get my hands on The Witcher 3, and those reasons were confirmed when I started playing Witcher 2.

Anyway, so far there is a big learning curve, but I love it!  Finally a CRPG that wasn't made for children, this is truly an adult's game.  No, it's not flagrantly adult for adult's sake, but it does deal with the reality of war, politics, love and whichever of the 7 deadly sins you wish to partake.  The medieval world this game presents is harsh, much like the real one 1000 years ago in Europe.  With all of the lore that our real Medieval Age created (dragons, magic, knights, highway robbery, witches, bestiary, etc), lore that we still dream about (don't tell me you haven't seen the Hobbit trilogy or the Lord of The Rings trilogy), this game does not come across as a child's movie.  We are entering a golden age of Computer Role Playing Games (CRPGs) with the advent of Witcher 3:  The Wild Hunt.  Skyrim gave us a glimpse of how things could be with an RPG on a computer platform or console when developers actually decide to do some real work instead of flowcharting everything into a nice neat little computer program that plays out more like a movie with the same ending.  Yes, all movies (except for maybe CLUE) have a single ending but to create a game that changes based on player-character choices, with 38 different endings, is a feat indeed my friends, quite a feat indeed.  This is next-gen programming and it opens a window to a whole new dimension of gaming.  This allows for real artificial intelligence, of which I believe will evolve through the high-end CRPG gaming industry because if NASA is developing it, you're not going to ever get to see it or even know about it.  HAL might exist now, but you're not hearing about it because there is the deep-seeded fear of true AI, it will never become pervasive if the government has anything to say about it.  However our society is in need of AI:  look at all of the controversy involved in bad calls in sports, video-recognition software exists but we continue to allow flawed humans to make these calls that affect millions of units of money (dollars, euros); don't you think doctors could use a second opinion too?  The vast databases of medical knowledge are not being used properly, we still rely on doctor's memories and research skills to find solutions.  AI could save lives, yet we look at it with the jaundiced eye of say, the Terminator series, or what HAL did in 2001 A Space Odyssey, or I Robot; the potential evil of AI has been laid out for all to see, that if we gave AI control, it would render humans useless and destroy us.  I think it's preposterous, we will need to develop AI for so many things in the future, a future that is becoming more and more complicated, we are going to need help.  Many things like space travel (who you gonna call when you're 3 light years away from earth and you need an answer within minutes or seconds, not the 3 years it would take to get the information to you?), medicine, navigation of flying cars (they're coming soon, but maybe not in our lifetime, but soon), virtual reality will require some tremendous AI (just ask Captain Picard about his misadventures in the Enterprise's holodeck), etc.  I quit ranting about AI but this should tell you about how excited I am about this game, and what promise for the future it portends.
summary: My CRPG game search for a time-filler before Witcher 3 release, brought me to Witcher 2 Enhanced Edition

reviewText: great game for adults

Great game. The folks at CDPR took a great game and came back with an even greater game. I have seen comments about the content and it was down rated because of it. It is in context with his character as he is a lusty sort and they chose to put it out there. In the first game, you had the sex cards. This one was better in that respect and I didn't find it distracting from the story line. Definitely not for the kids. I saw a comment about it giving an i5 a workout. If it was a Second Gen Sandy Bridge, it shouldn't have been an issue, but could have been taxing on the GPU, as it is rather GPU intensive and you need a good one. I have played it on both the GTX 560Ti and GTX 680. Both did fine with the settings maxed out ( except Blur effects, which I don't like ).
It is very much story driven and the decisions you make will determine which direction the game takes. Supposedly there are some 14 different endings. The graphics are lush. I have never cared much for QTE's but you can tone them down in this game. If you want hours of fun, then this is your game. It is not a straight slice and dice thing and involves some thinking and you need to pay attention to the story and where it is taking you, You can't just mindlessly wander around slicing and dicing. I am playing it again for the I don't know how many times.
summary: How do you beat a winner ?  CDPR has done just that with this sequel to their hit game, The Witcher.

reviewText: Not my type of game!

Have not heard of the witcher series until I saw the previews for Witcher 3 so I saw a YouTube video on the first witcher game to get the story and bought Witcher 2.
